document.docAuthor: Forges, Bertrand Richer De, Lee, Bee Yan & Ng, Peter K. L.
document.docTitle: Seiitaoides kabuto Forges & Lee & Ng 2021, n. sp.
document.masterDocTitle: The taxonomy of spider crabs of the genera Eurynome, Choniognathus, Seiitaiodes and Kasagia (Crustacea: Brachyura: Majidae) from southwest Indian Ocean

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The taxonomy of spider crabs of the genera Eurynome, Choniognathus, Seiitaiodes and Kasagia (Crustacea: Brachyura: Majidae) from southwest Indian Ocean

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material examined.
Holotype :
ovigerous female (cl 10.0 mm, pcl
8.6 m
, cw 5.3 mm , bcw 4.5 mm ) (MNHN-IU-2016-7089), stn DW4836, Comoros Islands , 1225’S 4356’E,
82–88 m
, coll. BIOMAGLO,
28 January 2017
.
Paratype :
1 female (cl 11.2 mm , pcl 9.3 mm , cw 5.7 mm , bcw 5.1 mm ) (MNHN-IU-2016-7090), 1 ovigerous female (cl 10.1 mm , pcl 8.6 mm , cw 5.3 mm , bcw 4.6 mm ) ( ZRC 2020.377 , ex MNHN-IU-2016-7088), same locality
and collection data as holotype .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 10.
Seiitaoides kabuto
n. sp.
A, B, holotype ovigerous female (cl 10.0 mm, cw 5.3 mm) (MNHN-IU-2016-7089), Comoros Islands; C, D, paratype ovigerous female (cl 10.1 mm, cw 5.3 mm) (ZRC 2020.377), Comoros Islands. A, C, overall view; B, D, dorsal view of carapace including swelling on pleonal somite 1.

FIGURE 11.
Seiitaoides kabuto
n. sp.
, holotype ovigerous female (cl 10.0 mm, cw 5.3 mm) (MNHN-IU-2016-7089), Comoros Islands. A, lateral view of cephalothorax; B, ventral view showing antennules, antennae, epistome, buccal cavity and third maxillipeds; C, left third maxilliped; D, outer view of left chela; E, right fourth ambulatory leg.

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. The name alludes to the general appearance of the carapace, superficially resembling a kabuto, the Japanese name for a samurai helmet. The name is used as a Latin noun in apposition.

The description and figure of
S. stimpsoni
by Miers (1884: 523 , pl. 47 fig. A) does not show an intercalated spine but it is probably present. In
S. kabuto
n. sp.
, the intercalated spine is small and tightly appressed against the supraocular eave and postocular spine with no gaps between them ( Fig. 10B, C ), so much so that the structures appear almost completely fused. It could thus have been easily missed by Miers.
